isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - Hydraulic Anti-Lock Braking System (HABS) Installation Guide for OEMs and Body Builders (Includes Body Builder Installation Information) - D VERSION HYDRAULIC ABS - BODY BUILDER INFORMATION

svcproc.title: D VERSION HYDRAULIC ABS - BODY BUILDER INFORMATION
svcproc.para: Before modifying a bus, truck or motor home chassis equipped with Meritor WABCO D version hydraulic ABS, review the following information. These tips will help you understand the ABS system and help avoid possible damage to that system when the chassis is altered. Typical Meritor WABCO Hydraulic ABS systems are illustrated in Figures of this bulletin.

item.para: Do not mount extreme heat sources (sources exceeding 158°F, 70°C) near the ECU. These include cab heater, engine exhaust, etc.
Do not install RFI-emitting devices (such as radios, electric motors or pumps) on or near the ECU or other ABS components to help isolate the system from electrical interference.
Perform all chassis welding with all connections to the ECU disconnected.
When installing other components, be aware of - and do not damage - the ABS harness or connectors.
Do not cut or splice the ABS harness to provide power to other sources on the vehicle. Cutting or splicing the ABS harness may cause the system to malfunction.
When extending an OEM chassis, use the appropriate ABS harness extension cables and connectors. Maintenance Manual 39, available from Meritor WABCO, provides installation information.
All ground connections of the modulator assembly and ECU MUST have separate grounding points. Meritor WABCO recommends that no other loads be connected to the grounds.
When painting or undercoating, make sure all connections are securely fastened. Protect unfastened or exposed connectors.
Any ABS component removed during modification must be reinstalled per Meritor WABCO specifications.
Before putting the vehicle into operation, perform the appropriate end of line test to ensure proper hydraulic ABS operation.
